data.source: 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey (FHCS) administered by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (survey)
data.wave_or_subset: 2006 FHCS; representative of full-time, permanent federal employees; analyses omit respondents planning to retire
data.notes: Race coded as white=1, nonwhite=0; agency tenure measured on a six-point ordinal scale; satisfaction with benefits constructed via factor analysis (eigenvalue=1.380, Cronbach’s alpha=0.76); performance culture constructed via factor analysis of four items (eigenvalue=2.407, Cronbach’s alpha=0.87); relationship with supervisor averaged from two items; gender missing for ~140,000 respondents and excluded from models; robust standard errors clustered by agency.

method.description: Cross-sectional analysis of U.S. federal employees using the 2006 FHCS. The study estimates two logistic regression models with robust standard errors clustered by agency to examine determinants of turnover intention: (1) intention to leave one’s agency for another federal job and (2) intention to leave the federal government for an external job. Predictors include demographic, workplace satisfaction, and organizational/relational variables, with interactions between age and satisfaction with benefits/advancement. Predicted probabilities and first differences are computed via Monte Carlo simulation.
steps: Obtain the 2006 Federal Human Capital Survey (FHCS) data from OPM.
Restrict to full-time, permanent employees and exclude respondents planning to retire.
Construct dependent variables: (a) Leaving Agency =1 if planning to leave agency for another federal job; (b) Leaving Government =1 if planning to leave federal government for an outside job.
Code demographics: age categories (under 30; 30–39; 40–49; 50–59; 60+), agency tenure (1–6 ordinal), race/ethnicity (white=1, nonwhite=0).

Measure workplace satisfaction: overall job satisfaction; satisfaction with pay; satisfaction with benefits (factor from retirement, health, life insurance items); satisfaction with advancement opportunity.

Measure organizational/relational factors: empowerment (single item); performance culture (factor from four merit/reward items); relationship with supervisor (average of trust/confidence and supervisor performance items); relationship with coworkers (single item).
Create interaction terms: age categories × satisfaction with advancement; age categories × satisfaction with benefits.
Estimate two logistic regression models (one per outcome) with robust standard errors clustered by agency.
Compute predicted probabilities and first differences using Monte Carlo simulations (Clarify).
Interpret results focusing on statistical significance and substantive effect sizes.
method.models: Two logistic regression (logit) models with robust standard errors clustered by agency; interactions between age and satisfaction with benefits/advancement; predicted probabilities via Monte Carlo simulation.
method.outcome_variable: Turnover intention measured as two dichotomous outcomes: (1) Leaving Agency (1 = intends to leave current agency for another federal job within one year; 0 = otherwise) and (2) Leaving Government (1 = intends to leave federal government for an outside position within one year; 0 = otherwise).
method.independent_variables: Age categories (30–39; 40–49; 50–59; 60+; base: under 30); agency tenure (six-point ordinal); race/ethnicity (white=1, nonwhite=0); overall job satisfaction; satisfaction with pay; satisfaction with benefits (factor); satisfaction with advancement; performance culture (factor from four reward/merit items); empowerment; relationship with supervisor (two-item average); relationship with coworkers; interactions: age × satisfaction with advancement; age × satisfaction with benefits.
method.control_variables: Age, agency tenure, race/ethnicity, job satisfaction, satisfaction with pay, satisfaction with benefits, satisfaction with advancement, performance culture, empowerment, relationship with supervisor, relationship with coworkers; interaction terms between age and satisfaction with advancement/benefits.
method.tools_software: Stata 11; Clarify program (King, Tomz, and Wittenberg, 2000) for predicted probabilities.

results.summary: Across more than 200,000 federal employees, higher overall job satisfaction consistently reduces turnover intention for both moving within the federal government and exiting federal service. Age exhibits a curvilinear pattern for leaving one’s agency (increases through mid-career then decreases) and a consistent negative association with intending to leave the federal government. Longer agency tenure reduces both types of turnover intentions. Whites (as coded) show higher intention to leave their agency and lower intention to leave the federal government relative to nonwhites per model coefficients and predicted probabilities presented. Satisfaction with pay negatively relates to turnover intentions but with small substantive effects. Satisfaction with benefits is positively associated with intending to leave one’s agency and unrelated to leaving government. Satisfaction with advancement strongly reduces intention to leave one’s agency and modestly reduces intention to leave government. A stronger performance culture slightly increases intention to leave one’s agency. Empowerment has a small negative association with intention to leave government and no effect on leaving one’s agency. Better supervisor relationships reduce intention to leave one’s agency; coworker relationships are not significant.
